trans-unit.source: tables and columns, revoking

seg-source.mrk: tables and columns, revoking

target.mrk: tables and columns, revoking

trans-unit.source: Use the REVOKE statement to remove privileges from a specific user or role, or from all users, to perform actions on database objects. You can also use the REVOKE statement to revoke a role from a user, from PUBLIC, or from another role.

seg-source.mrk: Use the REVOKE statement to remove privileges from a specific user or role, or from all users, to perform actions on database objects.
You can also use the REVOKE statement to revoke a role from a user, from PUBLIC, or from another role.

target.mrk: Use the REVOKE statement to remove privileges from a specific user or role, or from all users, to perform actions on database objects.
You can also use the REVOKE statement to revoke a role from a user, from PUBLIC, or from another role.

trans-unit.source: The following types of privileges can be revoked:

seg-source.mrk: The following types of privileges can be revoked:

target.mrk: The following types of privileges can be revoked:

trans-unit.source: Delete data from a specific table.

target.mrk: Delete data from a specific table.

trans-unit.source: The derby.database.sqlAuthorization property must be set to true before you can use the GRANT statement or the REVOKE statement. The derby.database.sqlAuthorization property enables SQL Authorization mode.

seg-source.mrk: The derby.database.sqlAuthorization property must be set to true before you can use the GRANT statement or the REVOKE statement.
The derby.database.sqlAuthorization property enables SQL Authorization mode.

target.mrk: The derby.database.sqlAuthorization property must be set to true before you can use the GRANT statement or the REVOKE statement.
The derby.database.sqlAuthorization property enables SQL Authorization mode.

trans-unit.source: You can revoke privileges for an object if you are the owner of the object or the <xref href="rrefattrib26867.dita#rrefattrib26867">database owner</xref>.

seg-source.mrk: You can revoke privileges for an object if you are the owner of the object or the <xref href="rrefattrib26867.dita#rrefattrib26867">database owner</xref>.

target.mrk: You can revoke privileges for an object if you are the owner of the object or the <xref href="rrefattrib26867.dita#rrefattrib26867">database owner</xref>.

trans-unit.source: The syntax that you use for the REVOKE statement depends on whether you are revoking privileges to a schema object or revoking a role.

seg-source.mrk: The syntax that you use for the REVOKE statement depends on whether you are revoking privileges to a schema object or revoking a role.

target.mrk: The syntax that you use for the REVOKE statement depends on whether you are revoking privileges to a schema object or revoking a role.

trans-unit.source: For more information on using the REVOKE statement, see "Using SQL standard authorization" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

seg-source.mrk: For more information on using the REVOKE statement, see "Using SQL standard authorization" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

target.mrk: For more information on using the REVOKE statement, see "Using SQL standard authorization" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

trans-unit.source: Syntax for tables

seg-source.mrk: Syntax for tables

target.mrk: Syntax for tables

trans-unit.source: REVOKE privilegeType ON [ TABLE ] { | } FROM revokees

seg-source.mrk: REVOKE privilegeType ON [ TABLE ] { | } FROM revokees

target.mrk: REVOKE privilegeType ON [ TABLE ] { | } FROM revokees

trans-unit.source: Revoking a privilege without specifying a column list revokes the privilege for all of the columns in the table.

seg-source.mrk: Revoking a privilege without specifying a column list revokes the privilege for all of the columns in the table.

target.mrk: Revoking a privilege without specifying a column list revokes the privilege for all of the columns in the table.

trans-unit.source: Syntax for routines

seg-source.mrk: Syntax for routines

target.mrk: Syntax for routines

trans-unit.source: REVOKE EXECUTE ON FUNCTION functionName FROM revokees RESTRICT

seg-source.mrk: REVOKE EXECUTE ON FUNCTION functionName FROM revokees RESTRICT

target.mrk: REVOKE EXECUTE ON FUNCTION functionName FROM revokees RESTRICT

trans-unit.source: REVOKE EXECUTE ON PROCEDURE procedureName FROM revokees RESTRICT

seg-source.mrk: REVOKE EXECUTE ON PROCEDURE procedureName FROM revokees RESTRICT

target.mrk: REVOKE EXECUTE ON PROCEDURE procedureName FROM revokees RESTRICT

trans-unit.source: You must use the RESTRICT clause on REVOKE statements for routines. The RESTRICT clause specifies that the EXECUTE privilege cannot be revoked if the specified routine is used in a view, trigger, or constraint, and the privilege is being revoked from the owner of the view, trigger, or constraint.

seg-source.mrk: You must use the RESTRICT clause on REVOKE statements for routines.

The RESTRICT clause specifies that the EXECUTE privilege cannot be revoked if the specified routine is used in a view, trigger, or constraint, and the privilege is being revoked from the owner of the view, trigger, or constraint.

target.mrk: You must use the RESTRICT clause on REVOKE statements for routines.

The RESTRICT clause specifies that the EXECUTE privilege cannot be revoked if the specified routine is used in a view, trigger, or constraint, and the privilege is being revoked from the owner of the view, trigger, or constraint.

trans-unit.source: Syntax for sequence generators

seg-source.mrk: Syntax for sequence generators

target.mrk: Syntax for sequence generators

trans-unit.source: REVOKE USAGE ON SEQUENCE sequenceName FROM revokees RESTRICT

seg-source.mrk: REVOKE USAGE ON SEQUENCE sequenceName FROM revokees RESTRICT

target.mrk: REVOKE USAGE ON SEQUENCE sequenceName FROM revokees RESTRICT

trans-unit.source: In order to use a sequence generator, you must have the USAGE privilege on it. This privilege can be revoked from users and roles. Only RESTRICTed revokes are allowed. This means that the REVOKE statement cannot make a view, trigger, or constraint unusable by its owner. The USAGE privilege cannot be revoked from the schema owner. See <xref href="rrefsqljcreatesequence.dita#rrefsqljcreatesequence"></xref> for more information.

seg-source.mrk: In order to use a sequence generator, you must have the USAGE privilege on it.
This privilege can be revoked from users and roles.
Only RESTRICTed revokes are allowed.
This means that the REVOKE statement cannot make a view, trigger, or constraint unusable by its owner.
The USAGE privilege cannot be revoked from the schema owner.
See <xref href="rrefsqljcreatesequence.dita#rrefsqljcreatesequence"></xref> for more information.

target.mrk: In order to use a sequence generator, you must have the USAGE privilege on it.
This privilege can be revoked from users and roles.
Only RESTRICTed revokes are allowed.
This means that the REVOKE statement cannot make a view, trigger, or constraint unusable by its owner.
The USAGE privilege cannot be revoked from the schema owner.
See <xref href="rrefsqljcreatesequence.dita#rrefsqljcreatesequence"></xref> for more information.

target.mrk: REVOKE USAGE ON TYPE typeName FROM revokees RESTRICT

trans-unit.source: In order to use a user-defined type, you must have the USAGE privilege on it. This privilege can be revoked from users and roles. Only RESTRICTed revokes are allowed. This means that the REVOKE statement cannot make a view, trigger, or constraint unusable by its owner. The USAGE privilege cannot be revoked from the schema owner. See <xref href="rrefsqljcreatetype.dita#rrefsqljcreatetype"></xref> for more information.

seg-source.mrk: In order to use a user-defined type, you must have the USAGE privilege on it.
This privilege can be revoked from users and roles.
Only RESTRICTed revokes are allowed.
This means that the REVOKE statement cannot make a view, trigger, or constraint unusable by its owner.
The USAGE privilege cannot be revoked from the schema owner.
See <xref href="rrefsqljcreatetype.dita#rrefsqljcreatetype"></xref> for more information.

target.mrk: In order to use a user-defined type, you must have the USAGE privilege on it.
This privilege can be revoked from users and roles.
Only RESTRICTed revokes are allowed.
This means that the REVOKE statement cannot make a view, trigger, or constraint unusable by its owner.
The USAGE privilege cannot be revoked from the schema owner.

seg-source.mrk: REVOKE USAGE ON DERBY AGGREGATE aggregateName FROM revokees RESTRICT

target.mrk: REVOKE USAGE ON DERBY AGGREGATE aggregateName FROM revokees RESTRICT

trans-unit.source: In order to use a user-defined aggregate, you must have the USAGE privilege on it. This privilege can be revoked from users and roles. Only RESTRICTed revokes are allowed. This means that the REVOKE statement cannot make a view or trigger unusable by its owner. The USAGE privilege cannot be revoked from the schema owner. See <xref href="rrefsqljcreateaggregate.dita#rrefsqljcreateaggregate"></xref> for more information.

seg-source.mrk: In order to use a user-defined aggregate, you must have the USAGE privilege on it.
This privilege can be revoked from users and roles.
Only RESTRICTed revokes are allowed.
This means that the REVOKE statement cannot make a view or trigger unusable by its owner.
The USAGE privilege cannot be revoked from the schema owner.
See <xref href="rrefsqljcreateaggregate.dita#rrefsqljcreateaggregate"></xref> for more information.

target.mrk: In order to use a user-defined aggregate, you must have the USAGE privilege on it.
This privilege can be revoked from users and roles.
Only RESTRICTed revokes are allowed.
This means that the REVOKE statement cannot make a view or trigger unusable by its owner.
The USAGE privilege cannot be revoked from the schema owner.

trans-unit.source: Syntax for roles

seg-source.mrk: Syntax for roles

trans-unit.source: Only the <xref href="rrefattrib26867.dita#rrefattrib26867">database owner</xref> can revoke a role.

trans-unit.source: tablePrivilege

seg-source.mrk: tablePrivilege

target.mrk: tablePrivilege

trans-unit.source: DELETE | INSERT | REFERENCES [ columnList ] | SELECT [ columnList ] | TRIGGER | UPDATE [ columnList ]

seg-source.mrk: DELETE | INSERT | REFERENCES [ columnList ] | SELECT [ columnList ] | TRIGGER | UPDATE [ columnList ]

trans-unit.source: columnList

seg-source.mrk: columnList

target.mrk: columnList

trans-unit.source: ( columnIdentifier [ , columnIdentifier ]* )

seg-source.mrk: ( columnIdentifier [ , columnIdentifier ]* )

target.mrk: ( columnIdentifier [ , columnIdentifier ]* )

trans-unit.source: Use the ALL PRIVILEGES privilege type to revoke all of the privileges from the user or role for the specified table. You can also revoke one or more table privileges by specifying a privilegeList.

seg-source.mrk: Use the ALL PRIVILEGES privilege type to revoke all of the privileges from the user or role for the specified table.
You can also revoke one or more table privileges by specifying a privilegeList.

target.mrk: Use the ALL PRIVILEGES privilege type to revoke all of the privileges from the user or role for the specified table.
You can also revoke one or more table privileges by specifying a privilegeList.

trans-unit.source: Use the DELETE privilege type to revoke permission to delete rows from the specified table.

seg-source.mrk: Use the DELETE privilege type to revoke permission to delete rows from the specified table.

target.mrk: Use the DELETE privilege type to revoke permission to delete rows from the specified table.

trans-unit.source: Use the INSERT privilege type to revoke permission to insert rows into the specified table.

seg-source.mrk: Use the INSERT privilege type to revoke permission to insert rows into the specified table.

target.mrk: Use the INSERT privilege type to revoke permission to insert rows into the specified table.

trans-unit.source: Use the REFERENCES privilege type to revoke permission to create a foreign key reference to the specified table. If a column list is specified with the REFERENCES privilege, the permission is revoked on only the foreign key reference to the specified columns.

seg-source.mrk: Use the REFERENCES privilege type to revoke permission to create a foreign key reference to the specified table.
If a column list is specified with the REFERENCES privilege, the permission is revoked on only the foreign key reference to the specified columns.

target.mrk: Use the REFERENCES privilege type to revoke permission to create a foreign key reference to the specified table.
If a column list is specified with the REFERENCES privilege, the permission is revoked on only the foreign key reference to the specified columns.

trans-unit.source: Use the SELECT privilege type to revoke permission to perform SELECT statements on a table or view. If a column list is specified with the SELECT privilege, the permission is revoked on only those columns. If no column list is specified, then the privilege is valid on all of the columns in the table.

seg-source.mrk: Use the SELECT privilege type to revoke permission to perform SELECT statements on a table or view.
If a column list is specified with the SELECT privilege, the permission is revoked on only those columns.
If no column list is specified, then the privilege is valid on all of the columns in the table.

target.mrk: Use the SELECT privilege type to revoke permission to perform SELECT statements on a table or view.
If a column list is specified with the SELECT privilege, the permission is revoked on only those columns.
If no column list is specified, then the privilege is valid on all of the columns in the table.

trans-unit.source: Use the TRIGGER privilege type to revoke permission to create a trigger on the specified table.

seg-source.mrk: Use the TRIGGER privilege type to revoke permission to create a trigger on the specified table.

target.mrk: Use the TRIGGER privilege type to revoke permission to create a trigger on the specified table.

trans-unit.source: Use the UPDATE privilege type to revoke permission to use the UPDATE statement on the specified table. If a column list is specified, the privilege is revoked only on the specified columns.

seg-source.mrk: Use the UPDATE privilege type to revoke permission to use the UPDATE statement on the specified table.
If a column list is specified, the privilege is revoked only on the specified columns.

target.mrk: Use the UPDATE privilege type to revoke permission to use the UPDATE statement on the specified table.
If a column list is specified, the privilege is revoked only on the specified columns.

trans-unit.source: revokees

seg-source.mrk: revokees

target.mrk: revokees

trans-unit.source: { authorizationIdentifier | roleName | PUBLIC } [ , { authorizationIdentifier | roleName | PUBLIC } ]*

seg-source.mrk: { authorizationIdentifier | roleName | PUBLIC } [ , { authorizationIdentifier | roleName | PUBLIC } ]*

target.mrk: { authorizationIdentifier | roleName | PUBLIC } [ , { authorizationIdentifier | roleName | PUBLIC } ]*

trans-unit.source: You can revoke the privileges from specific users or roles or from all users. Use the keyword PUBLIC to specify all users. The privileges revoked from PUBLIC and from individual users or roles are independent privileges. For example, a SELECT privilege on table <codeph>t</codeph> is revokeed to both PUBLIC and to the authorization ID <codeph>harry</codeph>. The SELECT privilege is later revoked from the authorization ID <codeph>harry</codeph>, but the authorization ID <codeph>harry</codeph> can access the table <codeph>t</codeph> through the PUBLIC privilege.

seg-source.mrk: You can revoke the privileges from specific users or roles or from all users.
Use the keyword PUBLIC to specify all users.
The privileges revoked from PUBLIC and from individual users or roles are independent privileges.
For example, a SELECT privilege on table <codeph>t</codeph> is revokeed to both PUBLIC and to the authorization ID <codeph>harry</codeph>.

The SELECT privilege is later revoked from the authorization ID <codeph>harry</codeph>, but the authorization ID <codeph>harry</codeph> can access the table <codeph>t</codeph> through the PUBLIC privilege.

target.mrk: You can revoke the privileges from specific users or roles or from all users.
Use the keyword PUBLIC to specify all users.
The privileges revoked from PUBLIC and from individual users or roles are independent privileges.
For example, a SELECT privilege on table <codeph>t</codeph> is revokeed to both PUBLIC and to the authorization ID <codeph>harry</codeph>.

The SELECT privilege is later revoked from the authorization ID <codeph>harry</codeph>, but the authorization ID <codeph>harry</codeph> can access the table <codeph>t</codeph> through the PUBLIC privilege.

trans-unit.source: You can revoke a role from a role, from a user, or from PUBLIC.

seg-source.mrk: You can revoke a role from a role, from a user, or from PUBLIC.

target.mrk: You can revoke a role from a role, from a user, or from PUBLIC.

trans-unit.source: You cannot revoke the privileges of the owner of an object.

seg-source.mrk: You cannot revoke the privileges of the owner of an object.

target.mrk: You cannot revoke the privileges of the owner of an object.

trans-unit.source: Prepared statements and open result sets/cursors

seg-source.mrk: Prepared statements and open result sets/cursors

target.mrk: Prepared statements and open result sets/cursors

trans-unit.source: Checking for privileges happens at statement execution time, so prepared statements are still usable after a revoke action. If sufficient privileges are still available for the session, prepared statements will be executed, and for queries, a result set will be returned.

seg-source.mrk: Checking for privileges happens at statement execution time, so prepared statements are still usable after a revoke action.
If sufficient privileges are still available for the session, prepared statements will be executed, and for queries, a result set will be returned.

target.mrk: Checking for privileges happens at statement execution time, so prepared statements are still usable after a revoke action.
If sufficient privileges are still available for the session, prepared statements will be executed, and for queries, a result set will be returned.

trans-unit.source: Once a result set has been returned to the application (by executing a prepared statement or by direct execution), it will remain accessible even if privileges or roles are revoked in a way that would cause another execution of the same statement to fail.

seg-source.mrk: Once a result set has been returned to the application (by executing a prepared statement or by direct execution), it will remain accessible even if privileges or roles are revoked in a way that would cause another execution of the same statement to fail.

target.mrk: Once a result set has been returned to the application (by executing a prepared statement or by direct execution), it will remain accessible even if privileges or roles are revoked in a way that would cause another execution of the same statement to fail.

trans-unit.source: Cascading object dependencies

seg-source.mrk: Cascading object dependencies

target.mrk: Cascading object dependencies

trans-unit.source: For views, triggers, and constraints, if the privilege on which the object depends on is revoked, the object is automatically dropped. <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> does not try to determine if you have other privileges that can replace the privileges that are being revoked. For more information, see "Using SQL standard authorization" and "Privileges on views, triggers, and constraints" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

seg-source.mrk: For views, triggers, and constraints, if the privilege on which the object depends on is revoked, the object is automatically dropped.
<ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> does not try to determine if you have other privileges that can replace the privileges that are being revoked.
For more information, see "Using SQL standard authorization" and "Privileges on views, triggers, and constraints" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

target.mrk: For views, triggers, and constraints, if the privilege on which the object depends on is revoked, the object is automatically dropped.
<ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> does not try to determine if you have other privileges that can replace the privileges that are being revoked.
For more information, see "Using SQL standard authorization" and "Privileges on views, triggers, and constraints" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

trans-unit.source: Limitations

seg-source.mrk: Limitations

target.mrk: Limitations

trans-unit.source: The following limitations apply to the REVOKE statement:

seg-source.mrk: The following limitations apply to the REVOKE statement:

target.mrk: The following limitations apply to the REVOKE statement:

trans-unit.source: Table-level privileges

seg-source.mrk: Table-level privileges

target.mrk: Table-level privileges

trans-unit.source: All of the table-level privilege types for a specified revokeee and table ID are stored in one row in the SYSTABLEPERMS system table. For example, when <codeph>user2</codeph> is revokeed the SELECT and DELETE privileges on table <codeph>user1.t1</codeph>, a row is added to the SYSTABLEPERMS table. The GRANTEE field contains <codeph>user2</codeph> and the TABLEID contains <codeph>user1.t1</codeph>. The SELECTPRIV and DELETEPRIV fields are set to Y. The remaining privilege type fields are set to N.

seg-source.mrk: All of the table-level privilege types for a specified revokeee and table ID are stored in one row in the SYSTABLEPERMS system table.
For example, when <codeph>user2</codeph> is revokeed the SELECT and DELETE privileges on table <codeph>user1.t1</codeph>, a row is added to the SYSTABLEPERMS table.
The GRANTEE field contains <codeph>user2</codeph> and the TABLEID contains <codeph>user1.t1</codeph>.
The SELECTPRIV and DELETEPRIV fields are set to Y. The remaining privilege type fields are set to N.

target.mrk: All of the table-level privilege types for a specified revokeee and table ID are stored in one row in the SYSTABLEPERMS system table.
For example, when <codeph>user2</codeph> is revokeed the SELECT and DELETE privileges on table <codeph>user1.t1</codeph>, a row is added to the SYSTABLEPERMS table.
The GRANTEE field contains <codeph>user2</codeph> and the TABLEID contains <codeph>user1.t1</codeph>.
The SELECTPRIV and DELETEPRIV fields are set to Y. The remaining privilege type fields are set to N.

trans-unit.source: When a revokeee creates an object that relies on one of the privilege types, the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> engine tracks the dependency of the object on the specific row in the SYSTABLEPERMS table. For example, <codeph>user2</codeph> creates the view <codeph>v1</codeph> by using the statement <codeph>SELECT * FROM user1.t1</codeph>, the dependency manager tracks the dependency of view <codeph>v1</codeph> on the row in SYSTABLEPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>). The dependency manager knows only that the view is dependent on a privilege type in that specific row, but does not track exactly which privilege type the view is dependent on.

seg-source.mrk: When a revokeee creates an object that relies on one of the privilege types, the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> engine tracks the dependency of the object on the specific row in the SYSTABLEPERMS table.

For example, <codeph>user2</codeph> creates the view <codeph>v1</codeph> by using the statement <codeph>SELECT * FROM user1.t1</codeph>, the dependency manager tracks the dependency of view <codeph>v1</codeph> on the row in SYSTABLEPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>).
The dependency manager knows only that the view is dependent on a privilege type in that specific row, but does not track exactly which privilege type the view is dependent on.

target.mrk: When a revokeee creates an object that relies on one of the privilege types, the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> engine tracks the dependency of the object on the specific row in the SYSTABLEPERMS table.

For example, <codeph>user2</codeph> creates the view <codeph>v1</codeph> by using the statement <codeph>SELECT * FROM user1.t1</codeph>, the dependency manager tracks the dependency of view <codeph>v1</codeph> on the row in SYSTABLEPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>).
The dependency manager knows only that the view is dependent on a privilege type in that specific row, but does not track exactly which privilege type the view is dependent on.

trans-unit.source: When a REVOKE statement for a table-level privilege is issued for a revokeee and table ID, all of the objects that are dependent on the revokeee and table ID are dropped. For example, if <codeph>user1</codeph> revokes the DELETE privilege on table <codeph>t1</codeph> from <codeph>user2</codeph>, the row in SYSTABLEPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>) is modified by the REVOKE statement. The dependency manager sends a revoke invalidation message to the view <codeph>user2.v1</codeph> and the view is dropped even though the view is not dependent on the DELETE privilege for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>).

seg-source.mrk: When a REVOKE statement for a table-level privilege is issued for a revokeee and table ID, all of the objects that are dependent on the revokeee and table ID are dropped.

For example, if <codeph>user1</codeph> revokes the DELETE privilege on table <codeph>t1</codeph> from <codeph>user2</codeph>, the row in SYSTABLEPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>) is modified by the REVOKE statement.

The dependency manager sends a revoke invalidation message to the view <codeph>user2.v1</codeph> and the view is dropped even though the view is not dependent on the DELETE privilege for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>).

target.mrk: When a REVOKE statement for a table-level privilege is issued for a revokeee and table ID, all of the objects that are dependent on the revokeee and table ID are dropped.

For example, if <codeph>user1</codeph> revokes the DELETE privilege on table <codeph>t1</codeph> from <codeph>user2</codeph>, the row in SYSTABLEPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>) is modified by the REVOKE statement.

The dependency manager sends a revoke invalidation message to the view <codeph>user2.v1</codeph> and the view is dropped even though the view is not dependent on the DELETE privilege for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>).

trans-unit.source: Column-level privileges

seg-source.mrk: Column-level privileges

target.mrk: Column-level privileges

trans-unit.source: Only one type of privilege for a specified revokeee and table ID are stored in one row in the SYSCOLPERMS system table. For example, when <codeph>user2</codeph> is revokeed the SELECT privilege on table <codeph>user1.t1</codeph> for columns c12 and c13, a row is added to the SYSCOLPERMS. The GRANTEE field contains <codeph>user2</codeph>, the TABLEID contains <codeph>user1.t1</codeph>, the TYPE field contains <codeph>S</codeph>, and the COLUMNS field contains <codeph>c12, c13</codeph>.

seg-source.mrk: Only one type of privilege for a specified revokeee and table ID are stored in one row in the SYSCOLPERMS system table.
For example, when <codeph>user2</codeph> is revokeed the SELECT privilege on table <codeph>user1.t1</codeph> for columns c12 and c13, a row is added to the SYSCOLPERMS.

The GRANTEE field contains <codeph>user2</codeph>, the TABLEID contains <codeph>user1.t1</codeph>, the TYPE field contains <codeph>S</codeph>, and the COLUMNS field contains <codeph>c12, c13</codeph>.

target.mrk: Only one type of privilege for a specified revokeee and table ID are stored in one row in the SYSCOLPERMS system table.
For example, when <codeph>user2</codeph> is revokeed the SELECT privilege on table <codeph>user1.t1</codeph> for columns c12 and c13, a row is added to the SYSCOLPERMS.

The GRANTEE field contains <codeph>user2</codeph>, the TABLEID contains <codeph>user1.t1</codeph>, the TYPE field contains <codeph>S</codeph>, and the COLUMNS field contains <codeph>c12, c13</codeph>.

trans-unit.source: When a revokeee creates an object that relies on the privilege type and the subset of columns in a table ID, the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> engine tracks the dependency of the object on the specific row in the SYSCOLPERMS table. For example, <codeph>user2</codeph> creates the view <codeph>v1</codeph> by using the statement <codeph>SELECT c11 FROM user1.t1</codeph>, the dependency manager tracks the dependency of view <codeph>v1</codeph> on the row in SYSCOLPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>), TYPE(S). The dependency manager knows that the view is dependent on the SELECT privilege type, but does not track exactly which columns the view is dependent on.

seg-source.mrk: When a revokeee creates an object that relies on the privilege type and the subset of columns in a table ID, the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> engine tracks the dependency of the object on the specific row in the SYSCOLPERMS table.

For example, <codeph>user2</codeph> creates the view <codeph>v1</codeph> by using the statement <codeph>SELECT c11 FROM user1.t1</codeph>, the dependency manager tracks the dependency of view <codeph>v1</codeph> on the row in SYSCOLPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>), TYPE(S).
The dependency manager knows that the view is dependent on the SELECT privilege type, but does not track exactly which columns the view is dependent on.

target.mrk: When a revokeee creates an object that relies on the privilege type and the subset of columns in a table ID, the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> engine tracks the dependency of the object on the specific row in the SYSCOLPERMS table.

For example, <codeph>user2</codeph> creates the view <codeph>v1</codeph> by using the statement <codeph>SELECT c11 FROM user1.t1</codeph>, the dependency manager tracks the dependency of view <codeph>v1</codeph> on the row in SYSCOLPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>), TYPE(S).
The dependency manager knows that the view is dependent on the SELECT privilege type, but does not track exactly which columns the view is dependent on.

trans-unit.source: When a REVOKE statement for a column-level privilege is issued for a revokeee, table ID, and type, all of the objects that are dependent on the revokeee, table ID, and type are dropped. For example, if <codeph>user1</codeph> revokes the SELECT privilege on column <codeph>c12</codeph> on table <codeph>user1.t1</codeph> from <codeph>user2</codeph>, the row in SYSCOLPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>), TYPE(S) is modified by the REVOKE statement. The dependency manager sends a revoke invalidation message to the view <codeph>user2.v1</codeph> and the view is dropped even though the view is not dependent on the column <codeph>c12</codeph> for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>), TYPE(S).

seg-source.mrk: When a REVOKE statement for a column-level privilege is issued for a revokeee, table ID, and type, all of the objects that are dependent on the revokeee, table ID, and type are dropped.

For example, if <codeph>user1</codeph> revokes the SELECT privilege on column <codeph>c12</codeph> on table <codeph>user1.t1</codeph> from <codeph>user2</codeph>, the row in SYSCOLPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>), TYPE(S) is modified by the REVOKE statement.

The dependency manager sends a revoke invalidation message to the view <codeph>user2.v1</codeph> and the view is dropped even though the view is not dependent on the column <codeph>c12</codeph> for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>), TYPE(S).

target.mrk: When a REVOKE statement for a column-level privilege is issued for a revokeee, table ID, and type, all of the objects that are dependent on the revokeee, table ID, and type are dropped.

For example, if <codeph>user1</codeph> revokes the SELECT privilege on column <codeph>c12</codeph> on table <codeph>user1.t1</codeph> from <codeph>user2</codeph>, the row in SYSCOLPERMS for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>), TYPE(S) is modified by the REVOKE statement.

The dependency manager sends a revoke invalidation message to the view <codeph>user2.v1</codeph> and the view is dropped even though the view is not dependent on the column <codeph>c12</codeph> for GRANTEE(<codeph>user2</codeph>), TABLEID(<codeph>user1.t1</codeph>), TYPE(S).

trans-unit.source: Roles

seg-source.mrk: Roles

target.mrk: Roles

trans-unit.source: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> tracks any dependencies on the definer's current role for views, constraints, and triggers. If privileges were obtainable only via the current role when the object in question was defined, that object depends on the current role. The object will be dropped if the role is revoked from the defining user or from PUBLIC, as the case may be. Also, if a contained role of the current role in such cases is revoked, dependent objects will be dropped. Note that dropping may be too pessimistic. This is because <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> does not currently make an attempt to recheck if the necessary privileges are still available in such cases.

seg-source.mrk: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> tracks any dependencies on the definer's current role for views, constraints, and triggers.
If privileges were obtainable only via the current role when the object in question was defined, that object depends on the current role.
The object will be dropped if the role is revoked from the defining user or from PUBLIC, as the case may be.
Also, if a contained role of the current role in such cases is revoked, dependent objects will be dropped.
Note that dropping may be too pessimistic.
This is because <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> does not currently make an attempt to recheck if the necessary privileges are still available in such cases.

target.mrk: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> tracks any dependencies on the definer's current role for views, constraints, and triggers.
If privileges were obtainable only via the current role when the object in question was defined, that object depends on the current role.
The object will be dropped if the role is revoked from the defining user or from PUBLIC, as the case may be.
Also, if a contained role of the current role in such cases is revoked, dependent objects will be dropped.
Note that dropping may be too pessimistic.
This is because <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> does not currently make an attempt to recheck if the necessary privileges are still available in such cases.

trans-unit.source: To revoke the SELECT privilege on table <codeph>t</codeph> from the authorization IDs <codeph>maria</codeph> and <codeph>harry</codeph>, use the following syntax:
